required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of TBS-2 Testosterone Gel in Women With Acquired Female Orgasmic Disorder
clinical_study.official_title: A Placebo-Controlled, Randomized, Double-Blind, Parallel-Group, Dose-Finding Trial to Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of TBS-2 Intranasal Testosterone Gel in Women With Acquired Female Orgasmic Disorder

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess and compare the effects of 3 dose strengths of TBS-2 intranasal testosterone gel to placebo on the occurrence of orgasm.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Orgasms Over an 84 Day Period Compared to Placebo Over the Entire Treatment Period

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Sexual Event Satisfaction Over a 28-day Period (Day 57 to Day 84) Compared to Baseline (Day -28 to Day 0)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Day -28 to Day 0) and End of Study (Day 57 to 84)
secondary_outcome.description: as measured by Monash Women's Health Program Female Sexual Satisfaction Questionnaire (MONASH WHP FSSQ) question 11. MONASH WHP FSSQ question 11 asks participants to comment on how satisfying they found the sex to be from "Not at all" to "Very much so". The lowest score is 1 and the highest is 9. All scores for each 28-day period were averaged. Change from baseline was obtained by subtracting baseline 28-day average from the 28-day period at the end of the study (Day 57 to 84).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Distress Due to Female Orgasmic Disorder From Day 0 Baseline to Day 84
secondary_outcome.description: as measured by Female Sexual Distress Scale (FSDS-DAO) Question #15 on Day 0 and 84, respectively. Question #15 evaluates the level of distress related to problems with orgasm. It is rated on a 5-point Likert scale (from 0 to 4, i.e. never [0], rarely [1], occasionally [2], frequently [3], or always [4]). Higher scores indicate more distress.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in Global Sexual Functioning From Day 0 to Day 84
secondary_outcome.description: as measured by Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI) on Day 0 and 84, respectively. The FSFI, a 19-item questionnaire, has been developed as a brief, multidimensional self-report instrument for assessing the key dimensions of sexual frustration in women. The questionnaire provides scores on 6 domains of sexual function (desire, arousal, lubrication, orgasm, satisfaction, and pain) as well as a total score. Fifteen items are rated on a 6-point Likert scale (from 0 to 5) and 4 items on a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 to 5). The scores are added and converted using a conversion factor so that the maximum score for each domain is 6. The overall FSFI score can range from 2 to 36. Higher scores indicate better or higher sexual function.

arm_group.description: Placebo intranasal gel administered prn, 2-8 hours before a planned sexual event
Low dose TBS-2 (0.6 mg) testosterone intranasal gel administered prn
Medium dose TBS-2 (1.2 mg) testosterone intranasal gel administered prn
High dose TBS-2 (1.8 mg) testosterone intranasal gel administered prn

intervention.description: placebo intranasal gel administered prn, 2-8 hours before a planned sexual event
Low dose testosterone intranasal gel administered prn 2-8 hrs before a planned sexual event
Medium dose testosterone intranasal gel administered prn 2-8 hrs before a planned sexual event
High dose testosterone intranasal gel administered prn 2-8 hrs before a planned sexual event

facility.name: Quality of Life Medical Research Center
Center for Marital and Sexual Health of South Florida
Center for Marital and Sexual Health Inc.
Columbus Center for Women's Health Research
San Antonio Psychiatric Research Center Dba Croft Group Research Center
University of Virginia Center for Psychiatric Clinical Research
The Robinson Institute University of Adelaide

outcome.title: Change in Sexual Event Satisfaction Over a 28-day Period (Day 57 to Day 84) Compared to Baseline (Day -28 to Day 0)
outcome.description: as measured by Monash Women's Health Program Female Sexual Satisfaction Questionnaire (MONASH WHP FSSQ) question 11. MONASH WHP FSSQ question 11 asks participants to comment on how satisfying they found the sex to be from "Not at all" to "Very much so". The lowest score is 1 and the highest is 9. All scores for each 28-day period were averaged. Change from baseline was obtained by subtracting baseline 28-day average from the 28-day period at the end of the study (Day 57 to 84).
outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Day -28 to Day 0) and End of Study (Day 57 to 84)
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed is equal to the number of participants who completed the Day 84 visit.

outcome.title: Change in Global Sexual Functioning From Day 0 to Day 84
outcome.description: as measured by Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI) on Day 0 and 84, respectively. The FSFI, a 19-item questionnaire, has been developed as a brief, multidimensional self-report instrument for assessing the key dimensions of sexual frustration in women. The questionnaire provides scores on 6 domains of sexual function (desire, arousal, lubrication, orgasm, satisfaction, and pain) as well as a total score. Fifteen items are rated on a 6-point Likert scale (from 0 to 5) and 4 items on a 5-point Likert scale (from 1 to 5). The scores are added and converted using a conversion factor so that the maximum score for each domain is 6. The overall FSFI score can range from 2 to 36. Higher scores indicate better or higher sexual function.
outcome.population: The number of participants analyzed is equal to the number of participants who completed the Day 84 visit.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There IS an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Dr. Nathan Bryson, Chief Scientific Officer
